rev.comment: switched back to Wikipedia image - commons image is copyright violation
/* Post-war reign */ "His Majesty", "Her Majesty", "His Royal Highness", "Her Imperial Highness", etc., as formal titles, are always capitalized in English.-Writtenright
/* Post-war reign */ "Minister of Welfare" is the formal title, as in "Secretary of State".-Writtenright
/* Last days of the war */ In "power" is not a good word to use for post-WWII Hirohito; what "power"? "In office" is really much more to the point.-Writtenright
/* Last days of the war */ "...the Emperor's own lexicon" means "...the Emperor's own dictionary". Better to just say, "...between standard Japanese speech and the Emperor's (speech)".-Writtenright
/* Last days of the war */ Capital "P" here because "Prince" is part of his formal title (as in "Prince Ranier", "Prince Charles", etc.).-Writtenright
/* Last days of the war */ Verbs changed from present to past tense.-Writtenright
/* Early reign */ There was some strange trash at the end of this section. Deleted.
